title: Why is Mikael's more bell than crucible?
body:
Why does {{item:3222}} look more like a bell than a crucible?  If you compare it to a [picture of a real crucible](http://i01.i.aliimg.com/photo/v0/100604635/Arcual_Ceramic_Crucible_CH_3_2_.jpg), you can see that the icon seems to be upside-down and it doesn't look like you could actually put anything into it, as it can't really balance with that little knob on top.  I'd like to imagine there's a lid on top of it that could be opened, but, it really doesn't look that way as the two bands down the sides make it look like it's one solid piece.

The more I look at it, the more I see a bell rather than a crucible.  Was the name changed partway through after the icon was already finished or something?  I like the icon just fine, I just have a hard time seeing how it could possibly be any sort of crucible.

replies.body:
>A pickaxe plus a sword equals a bow. I don't understand.

It's because of the angles! :D The pickaxe has the arc, and the longsword is the arrow!

Actually no it doesn't make sense at all.

Take the book. Rip the pages out. Strap them to the shield. Put a stick you find randomly around in the shield(since you found it it's free).

Fire gem is a special fire gem for Mt. Doom. Or something like that. Which will char wood so much it hardens it. Take Phase, grind it on a rock you found on the ground(again free) then char it with the fire. 

Take Hexteck. Write about it in the book. Throw hexteck away. 

Perfect sense. 

For Last Whisper. 

Take the rod out of the axe. Take the rope wrapped around the swords hilt. Tie along the sides of the axe. Stick sword through axe. 
No one ever said Last Whisper was good at firing arrows. It's the power of decoration.

it makes perfect sense. 

Last whisper is a big bow that fires a sword that has the shaft of a pickaxe.

the banner of command is a whittled down plank from the other side of the shield and a page from the book put together.

the black cleaver is the shaft of the hammer plus an axe head made from a kindlegem and stained black.

Will of the ancients is a rebinding of the fiendish codex with many pages removed so you can hide a pistol in it.

Last Whisper - Named in honor of a valiant soldier who died after an intense battle from his infected wounds, in a delusional fever he muttered "A pick and a sword." as his Last Whisper.

Banner of Command: An ancient artifact utilized by novice Solari soldiers, this replaces their Aegis, it is said that strange sorceries are utilized in its creation.

Black Cleaver: This strange axe holds a vitality of its own, its swings seem to devour armor, rather than sunder.

Will of the Ancients: The version on Summoner's Rift is a recreation, the original methods to create such a book are lost to time. Created by combining the magical essence of Hextech Weaponry with traditional sorcery, the arts described in this book seem to rejuvenate the caster.

It makes perfect sens...

{{item:3222}} is a {{item:3028}} turned upside down over a {{item:3114}}. It's called as "crucible" because it's designed to hold the mana generated from the forbiden idol in liquid form. And yes, if you ask, the resonation of the mana trying to escape makes the crucible make it pretty hot.  That's why you have to pay more for the combination, because you need to make your chalice heat resistant and add a lid under it to release the mana at will.

Of course when the liquid mana explode and recover it plasmic form in the air, it disrupt all magic enchantment like roots, stun and slows.
Well, it may be a little off-topic, but isn't 180 seconds cooldown a little TOO long? You can use it once every 3 teamfights and the flat stats are not even worth(74.94% gold efficiency).
The ability to get rid of cc and heal is monumentally powerful though. It's an incredibly powerful item by the raw strength of its active.

I always thought it looked like maybe the back view of a long  cape or cloak or something
 {{item:1018}} {{item:1057}} {{item:2053}}

I actually had to look up crucibles to check, and I was convinced Mikael's could still work as a crucible...except that crucibles are meant to contain metals that are to be melted, which actually is pretty counter to the active unless it's liquid metal healing our allies, and that seems very unlikely.

Not even the second definition of crucible leads in to something better, so in reality not only is crucible not an accurate name for its appearance but also its function. TIL.

Easy fix would be to change the name from crucible to something else, perhaps make it a bell or water containing implement, but I feel like that would just confuse people.

cru·ci·ble
ˈkro͞osəb(ə)l/
noun
noun: crucible; plural noun: crucibles

    a ceramic or metal container in which metals or other substances may be melted or subjected to very high temperatures.
        a place or occasion of severe test or trial.
        "the crucible of combat"
        a place or situation in which different elements interact to produce something new.
        "the crucible of the new Romantic movement"

It would fit the last definition. It would be where different elements interact to produce something new, it could also be a metal container where metals (or other materials) may be melted or subjected to very high temperatures. It probably holds liquefied mana.

The occasion of severe test or trial would be determining when to use its store of mana to heal / break crowd control.
I've got a fever.  And the only prescription is more cruci-bell.

Crucible can have different definitions.

The other two that google provided was: 

"a place or occasion of severe test or trial."
"a place or situation in which different elements interact to produce something new." (note, this isn't the type of crucible you're talking about, this is more of a symbolic meaning of what you're talking about, as if you are comparing something TO a crucible, but it's a phrase that was used enough to change the meaning of the word

It could mean that that item is the product of Mikael combining two things, or to achieve that,  you would need to pass a test that Mikael set up, and that is the fruit of the effort.

Crucible is one of those words that means so many flexible things that you can come up with a number of backstories that might make sense, it doesn't have to be a literal crucible.

Because while we're at it, almost none of the swords in the game look remotely realistic, and some of them are hilariously inaccurate , like {{item:3139}}

Here's a picture of what a real scimitar looks like:  http://windlass.com/wp-content/themes/windlass/product-imagery/swords-knives-daggers/scimitar/scimitar-2.jpg

It's a fantasy game, so I don't really care if it looks oddly proportioned, it's just the art style, but pretty much every single sword in the game is oddly proportioned or has a very impractical design that would get you killed in real life.  {{item:1038}} for example has a hilt that is much too thick, and way too short.  If it were a real sword it looks like it would only be 2 or 3 feet in length in the first place.
